1974 ''[[Mahler (film)|Mahler]]'' }} }} '''Georgina Hale''' (born 4 August 1943) is an award-winning [[England|English]] [[actress]] notable for many stage, film and television appearances; often in the works of director [[Ken Russell]] and writer [[Simon Gray]]. She is perhaps best known for her [[BAFTA]]-winning performance as [[Alma Mahler]] in the 1974 film, ''[[Mahler (film)|Mahler]]''. In 2010, Hale was featured in an article in the British newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]'', where she was ranked third in a list of ten great [[character actor]]s in British television.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/gallery/2010/jul/27/british-character-actors|title=Looks Familiar: 10 great British character actors|publisher=guardian.co.uk|accessdate=September 19, 2010 | location=London | date=August 3, 2010}} ==Life and early career== Hale was born in [[Ilford]], [[England]], to George Robert Hale and Dorothy (nÃ©e Fordham).{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/15/Georgina-Hale.html|title=Georgina Hale Biography (1943-)|publisher=FilmReference.com|accessdate=May 17, 2009}} Poorly educated as a child, Hale was unable to read or write for many years.{{cite web|url=http://www.t-room.co.uk/georginainterview.php |title=Georgina Hale Interview|publisher=T-Room.co.uk|accessdate=May 17, 2009}} As a teenager, she worked as an apprentice hairdresser and studied acting at a [[Stanislavski Method]] studio in [[London]], before being accepted into the [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]]. ==Acting career== ===Stage=== An accomplished stage actress, Hale made her professional debut at Stratford as a walk-on. She subsequently appeared in rep at Canterbury, Windsor and Ipswich; then at the Liverpool Playhouse in 1967, where her parts included the title role in ''[[Gigi]]'', and Juliet in ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]''. At the Thorndike Theatre in Leatherhead in October 1975 she played Liza Doolittle in ''[[Pygmalion (play)|Pygmalion]]'', followed by an acclaimed portrayal of Nina in [[Anton Chekhov|Chekhov]]'s ''[[The Seagull]]'' at the Derby Playhouse in July 1976, making her West End debut in the production when it transferred to the Duke of York's Theatre in August 1976.Who's Who in the Theatre, 17th edition (1981) Other roles included: Marie Caroline David in ''The Tribades'' (Hampstead, May 1978); Melanie in ''Boo Hoo'' (Open Space, July 1978); and Bobbi Michele in ''[[The Last of the Red Hot Lovers]]'' (Royal Exchange, Manchester, April 1979 - transferring to the [[Criterion Theatre]] in November 1979). In 1981, Hale played the role of Josie in Nell Dunnâs play, ''[[Steaming (play)|Steaming]]'', at the [[Comedy Theatre]] in London. Hale received a 1981 Best Comedy Performance [[Olivier Awards|Olivier Award]] nomination for her performance.{{cite web|url=http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/olivier_awards/view/item98515/Olivier-Winners-1981-/|title=1981 Olivier Award Nominees|publisher=Officiallondontheatre.com|accessdate=May 17, 2009}} A year later in April 1982 she starred opposite [[Glenda Jackson]] in ''Summit Conference'' at the Lyric Theatre, playing [[Benito Mussolini]]'s mistress [[Clara Petacci]] in a revival of [[Citizens_Theatre#Robert_David_MacDonald|Robert David MacDonald]]'s play for the Glasgow [[Citizens Theatre]].Theatre Record Index, 1982 Over the years, Hale has made numerous appearances with the Citizens. These include ''[[Mourning Becomes Electra]]'' (1991), ''[[The Milk Train Doesn't Stop Here Anymore|The Milk Train Doesnât Stop Here Anymore]]'' (1994), ''[[Britannicus (play)|Britannicus]]'' (2002) and [[Anton Chekhov|Chekhov]]âs ''[[The Cherry Orchard]]'' (2002). Other notable stage appearances include [[Simon Gray]]'s ''[[Life Support]]'', opposite [[Alan Bates]], at the [[Aldwych Theatre]] in London (1997), [[Noel Coward]]âs ''[[Semi-Monde]]'' at the [[Lyric Theatre (London)|Lyric Theatre]] (2001), [[Roger Hall]]'s ''Take A Chance On Me'' at the [[New End Theatre]] (2003), and as Nell in [[Samuel Beckett]]âs ''[[Endgame (play)|Endgame]]'' at the [[Barbican Centre]] (2006). ===Film=== Haleâs most notable film role is arguably that of [[Alma Mahler]] in [[Ken Russell]]âs ''[[Mahler (film)|Mahler]]'' (1974), a [[biopic]] of the [[Austria]]n [[composer]] and [[Conducting|conductor]], [[Gustav Mahler]]. Hale received the 1974 Most Promising Newcomer [[BAFTA]] Film Award for her performance.{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/awards/film/nominations/?year=1974|title=1974 Bafta Winners|publisher=Bafta.org|accessdate=May 17, 2009}} Hale also made appearances in a number of [[Ken Russell|Russell]]âs other films, with supporting roles in ''[[The Devils (film)|The Devils]]'' (1971), and ''[[The Boyfriend]]'' (1971), and cameo roles in ''[[Lisztomania (film)|Lisztomania]]'' (1975), ''[[Valentino (1977 film)|Valentino]]'' (1977), and ''[[Treasure Island]]'' (1995).{{quote box|width=25%|align=right|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|quote="Georgina Hale...an actress of such sensitivity that she can make the hair rise on your arms."|source=[[Ken Russell]], 2007{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article2348755.ece|title=Actresses Who Have Bewitched Me - Ken Russell|publisher=TimesOnline.com|accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London | date=August 30, 2007}}}} Hale had a small role in the 1980 [[Walt Disney Productions|Walt Disney]] film ''[[The Watcher in the Woods]]'', starring [[Bette Davis]]. Hale took the role of the younger version of Davisâ character largely because of her admiration for Davis.{{cite video | people = [[John Hough (director)|Hough, John]] | title = The Watcher in the Woods | medium = DVD | publisher = [[Anchor Bay Entertainment]], [[Walt Disney Pictures]] | location = |date =2002 }} Subsequent film appearances include supporting roles in ''[[Butley (film)|Butley]]'' (1974), ''[[McVicar (film)|McVicar]]'' (1980), ''[[Castaway (film)|Castaway]]'' (1986), ''[[Preaching to the Perverted]]'' (1997), ''[[Mrs Palfrey at the Claremont]]'' (2005), and ''Cockneys VS Zombies'' (2011). ===Television=== Hale's television career spans five decades. Her first major television appearances were opposite [[Adam Faith]] in the [[ITV]] series, ''[[Budgie (TV series)|Budgie]]'' (1971â1972) and as Lili Dietrich in the [[miniseries]] ''[[The Strauss Family]]'' (1972). In 1975, Hale featured in two television plays written by Simon Gray. These were ''Plaintiffs and Defendants'' and ''Two Sundays'', broadcast as part of the [[ITV]] series, ''[[Play for Today]]'' (1975). In 1990, Hale succeeded [[Elizabeth Estensen]] in the eponymous role of ''[[T-Bag]]'', the villainous, tea drinking sorceress in a succession of childrenâs adventure series produced by [[Thames Television]]. Hale played the role in four series and two Christmas specials broadcast between 1990-1992. Other notable television appearances include guest starring roles in ''[[Upstairs, Downstairs]]'' (1975), ''[[Minder (TV series)|Minder]]'' (1980), ''[[Hammer House of Horror]]'' (1980), the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' serial ''[[The Happiness Patrol]]'' (1988), ''[[One Foot in the Grave]]'' (1990), ''[[Murder Most Horrid]]'' (1994), ''[[The Bill]]'' (2002), ''[[Emmerdale]]'' (2006), and ''[[The Commander (television series)|The Commander]]'' (2007). From from September 2010 to February 2011, Hale appeared as [[Blanche_Longford#Blanche_Longford|Blanche Longford]] in the long-running, British [[soap opera]] ''[[Hollyoaks]]''. ==Work== ===Filmography=== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%;" border="2" cellpadding="4" background: #f9f9f9; |- align="center" ! style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Year ! style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Film ! style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Role ! style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Notes |- |rowspan=2|1971 |''[[The Devils (film)|The Devils]]'' |Phillippe | |- |''[[The Boy Friend]]'' |Fay | |- |1972 |''[[Eagle in a Cage]]'' |Betty Balcombe | |- |1973 |''The Love Ban'' |Joyce | |- |rowspan=2|1974 |''[[Mahler (film)|Mahler]]'' |[[Alma Mahler]] |Received BAFTA Award for Most Promising Newcomer |- |''[[Butley (film)|Butley]]'' |Carol Heasman | |- |1975 |''[[Lisztomania (film)|Lisztomania]]'' |Cameo Appearance | |- |1976 |''[[Voyage of the Damned]]'' |Lotte Schulman | |- |1978 |''[[Sweeney 2]]'' |Switchboard Girl | |- |1979 |''[[The World Is Full of Married Men]]'' |Lori Grossman | |- |rowspan=2|1980 |''[[The Watcher in the Woods]]'' |Young Mrs Aylwood | |- |''[[McVicar (film)|McVicar]]'' |Kate | |- |1986 |''[[Castaway (film)|Castaway]]'' |Sister Saint Margaret | |- |1994 |''Beyond Bedlam'' |Sister Romulus | |- |1995 |''[[Jackson: My Life...
